title: Prince George's schools chief Kevin Maxwell gets four more years
text:
Prince George’s schools chief Kevin Maxwell gets four more years The inside track on Washington politics. Be the first to know about new stories from PowerPost. Sign up to follow, and we’ll e-mail you free updates as they’re published. You’ll receive free e-mail news updates each time a new story is published. You’re all set! By Arelis R. Hernández By Arelis R. Hernández February 17 at 4:43 PM Follow @arelisrhdz 
Prince George’s County Executive Rushern L. Baker III (D) announced Friday he was extending the contract for schools CEO Kevin Maxwell, giving the educator another four years to continue reform efforts despite recent abuse scandals that led to calls for Maxwell’s resignation . 
It is the first time in nearly 25 years that a superintendent in Prince George’s County will get a second term. Before Maxwell, the state’s second-largest school system had seven different superintendents in less than two decades. 
Maxwell is paid just under $300,000 a year. He was appointed by Baker in 2013, shortly after the county executive was awarded broad new power over school-system governance by the state legislature. 
His leadership is a central part of Baker’s plan to overhaul and stabilize Maryland’s second-largest public school system, after years of scandal, poor performance and dwindling public trust. 
Maxwell, who grew up in and began his career in Prince George’s County, has seen graduation rates reach record highs at some schools. Enrollment and some test scores also have increased. 
He expanded full-day prekindergarten and language-immersion offerings and increased participation in dual-enrollment programs that allow high school students to take college-level courses. 
But the system faced sexual and child abuse cases last year involving school personnel, including a one-time aide who now faces decades in prison. The allegations led to a federal investigation and the loss of control by the school system of millions of dollars in Head Start funding. [ For years, Pr. George’s did not strengthen school sex-abuse policies ] 
“It has been challenging but at the same time, it’s been some of the most rewarding work that I have ever done,” Maxwell said at a news conference at DuVal High School, where he introduced a specialized academic program focused on aerospace science. 
Maxwell described letters he has received from grateful students, the number of strategic business and philanthropic partnerships school officials have brokered and a more than $44 million increase in the value of scholarships offered to county graduates in 2016. 
“I see this as my capstone for my career,” the schools chief said. “I see this as my legacy and reinvesting in the community that gave me the life that I have today.” 
More than three dozen business, government, philanthropic leaders and school board members attended the announcement, giving Maxwell a standing ovation as he ticked off his administration’s accomplishments. [ How a Maryland school system lost its Head Start grant ] 
Absent were at least three elected members of the Board of Education, including Edward Burroughs, one of Maxwell’s most strident critics. He led calls for Maxwell to step down following revelations that a Head Start worker forced a child to mop up their own urine and texted a photo to the child’s mother. 
Amid the fallout, Maxwell asked his chief of staff to resign over an email that appeared to suggest school administrators tried to keep the Head Start scandal quiet. 
There were separate allegations of abuse involving a school bus aide accused of molesting students. 
Baker, who is term-limited in 2018, said he “never lost confidence” in Maxwell through all the “bumps and stumbles.” 
“Have we had problems? Yes,” Baker said. “The question is how we react … I want him to continue the work he is doing.” local
